Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Treating Addiction with Virtual Reality
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide a new modality for delivering effective substance abuse interventions. This project involves a novel virtual-reality based intervention to be applied in substance abuse treatment. The team plans to investigate customer potential for a turnkey software intervention that can be integrated into the treatment of substance use disorders. This intervention may save lives and money by significantly reducing relapse rates.

This I-Corps project explores how virtual reality may be an immediately available intervention to prevent relapse during periods of craving. Preliminary interviews suggest that virtual reality can regulate emotion for a period of hours or days after a brief 30-minute session. Substance abuse develops as a maladaptive response to strong negative emotions - if virtual reality can regulate emotion, it may serve as an alternative behavior that can be sought during potential moments of relapse. Prevention of relapse could combat the opioid epidemic and also help the millions of people who are addicted to other substances.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The I-Corps process was instrumental in helping us to explore the feasibility of commercializing our technology. Prior to beginning the I-Corps program, we had a virtual reality intervention that appeared to be effective in treating substance use disorders. In order to continue building and disseminating our intervention we realized we needed to explore how we could transfer our technology into the real world through commercialization. 

The I-Corps course taught us key business concepts (e.g., value propositions, customer segments, channels) that we had not learned in our academic training. During the six week course we conducted over 150 customer discovery interviews and tested hypotheses to build our canvas. Throughout the rest of the year we conducted an additional 70 customer discovery interviews as we honed our business model canvas.

We identified specific customer segments (e.g., Chief Financial Officers of rehabilitation centers, parents of emerging adults with substance use disorders) and met with organizations that became key strategic partners. We explored how our unique approach would provide value to patients, identified the barriers of existing approaches, established channels and partners, and narrowed the scope of our intervention.

As a result of the NSF I-CORPS process our entrepreneurial lead, Noah Robinson, founded Very Real Help LLC to build and disseminate this intervention. We identified a key problem: overdose-related deaths are steadily increasing, and interventions are ineffective and costly. In addition, existing interventions are time-limited and do not allow for a longitudinal time period for continuing care. Our proposed solution is a new type of intervention—if we can make our treatment more accessible than substances, we may be able to prevent relapse and effectively treat substance use disorders.

We are continuing to apply the lean startup model through collaboration with our strategic commercial partner. As we build and validate our assumptions as they relate to the execution of our business model, our partner will help us to validate our go-to market strategy, revenue model, and ultimately the best strategy for gaining critical mass. Our partner also facilitates access to patients for user-center design and hypothesis testing. 

Due to our commercial partner, VRH is afforded the opportunity to accelerate the lean startup model to launching our business. This includes tapping into the partner’s patient base (e.g., customer segment), strategic partners (e.g., employee assistance programs), and experiential expertise of navigating this market. 

Lastly, we leveraged the concepts and customer discovery from I-Corps to submit an STTR application to the National Institute on Drug Abuse. We believe that the I-Corps program was instrumental in catalyzing the commercialization of our virtual reality technology. We will continue to apply these concepts as we move forward.
